author_label: Ali bin al Mugrab Al Uyuni
physical_description: Extent: 309 leaves : paper ; 206 x 140 (155 x 90) mm. bound to 206 x 155 mm.
note: Collation: Paper ; fol. i + 309 + ii ; catchwords ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Description: Rubricated ; both pastedowns and the leaf opposite striated with brown ink ; MS in good condition.|Layout: 17-18 lines per page ; partially frame-ruled in red.|Marginal notes and glosses. Folio preceding title page, which is mended, has a table of necrology. On page preceding title page is a statement about Jarīr as the best poet in Islam with some of his verses. On folio after colophon are several verses by unknown authors. The dīwān is of special historical value because in it the author recites military exploits of his ancestors in war against the Qarmaṭians of al-Baḥrayn during fifth and sixth Muslim centuries.|Ms. codex.|Title from text (fol. 2b).|Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

physical_description: Extent: 60 leaves : paper ; 174 x 130 (130 x 90) mm bound to 174 x 136 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from collective title page (fol. 1a).|Marginal notes by a later hand on folio 44. On folio 17a is a ʻʻtree of poetryʼʼ entitled "The Tree Comprising the Rising Stars." It contains the names of the Prophet and his Companions. Folio 28, on which the second poem begins, has been marked by a later hand with a blue silk thread stitched into it. The dates of composition of both poems are mentioned in the last verses of each, the first being 860 1456 and the second 857 1453. Both were first written in the enclosure around the Kaʻbah. Page immediately after the colophon has a number of medical prescriptions for poisoned wounds and information on the use of banj (bhang).|Collation: Paper ; fol. i + 60 ; catchwords ; watermarks (later endpapers only) ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Layout: 11 lines per page.|Description: Written in alternating black and red ink ; vowel signs ; MS in good condition, some pages mended. Folio 1 appears to be a replacement.|Ownership signatures: Muḥammad ibn Muṣṭafá dated 1039, ʻAbd al-ʻĀdil? Makkī al-Ṭūṭī? dated 1251 (fol. 1a). Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

physical_description: Extent: 321 leaves : paper ; 192 x 134 (155 x 90) mm. bound to 198 x 140 mm.
note: Collation: Paper ; fol. 321 + 1 ; catchwords ; pagination in red ink using Hindi-Arabic numerals ; quires signed 1-32 ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Description: Rubricated ; verse separators in red ; MS is in good condition and very neat ; MS is rare.|Layout: 20-22 lines per page with separation between hemistitches.|Marginal notes and glosses. On the title page are four verses of poetry by a transcriber, Ramaḍān al-ʻAṭīfī. On four folios before the title page is an index of the names in the MS; following is a statement to the effect that MS was written at the request and at the expense of Aḥmad Wihbi Wahbah, a bookseller in Ḥalab. He also collated the MS himself.|Ms. codex.|Origin: According to colophon copied Thursday 19 Muḥarram 1305 by Muḥammad ʻAbd al-ʻAzīz ibn/al-Mardīn Muḥammad Rāghib (fol. 321a).|Title from title page (fol. 5a).|Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

author_as_recorded: Rashīdī, ʻAbd al-Raḥmān ibn Muḥammad, active 14th century
author_as_recorded_agr: رشيدي، عبد الرحمن بن محمد، 14th century
physical_description: Extent: (1), 108 leaves : paper ; 254 x 172 (185 x 120) mm. bound to 174 x 255 mm.
note: Collation: Paper ; fol. (1) + 108 + ii ; catchwords ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Description: Rubicated ; verse separators and other use of red ; some headings and other words overwritten in red ink, possibly at a later time or by a different hand ; MS in poor condition with a number of repairs and some staining.|Layout: 17-19 lines per page.|Marginal notes and glosses in different hands. On title page is a statement showing the wisdom of the Prophetʼs having been born on a Monday in Rabīʻ I, a statement that the MS was written by the author himself. On page after colophon are a quotation of verse and prose ascribed to al-Shāfiʻī, another ascribed to Abū Zayd al-Bisṭāmī and eight verses of poetry entitled al-Mukhammas al-Laṭīf.|Ms. codex.|Origin: According to colophon copied 23 Jumādá al-Awwal 774 by the author (fol. 108b).|Title from title page (fol. 1a).|Ownership signatures: Ibrāhīm ibn al-Raʼīs Muḥammad al-Zaman dated 1180, Muḥammad Ṣāliḥ ibn Ibrāhīm al-Raʼīs dated 1208 (fol. 1a). Under the colophon on the same page are two autographs of owners, one an Imām of a Madrasah. Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

author_as_recorded: Qīrāṭī, Ibrāhīm ibn ʻAbd Allāh, 1326-1379 or 1380
scribe_as_recorded: Mālikī, Muḥammad ibn Aḥmad, active 15th century
scribe_as_recorded_agr: مالكي، محمد بن احمد، active 15th century
physical_description: Extent: (4), 128, (1) leaves : paper ; 177 x 135 (125 x 95) mm bound to 177 x 142 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Marginal notes and glosses in different hand. The work has been collected by Badr al-Dīn Muḥammad ibn Burhān al-Dīn Ibrāhīm ibn Muḥammad al-Subkī, whose name is mentioned on folios 4, 50 and 122. Title page and perhaps a few folios are missing. On the two folios after the colophon is an ode by Ismāʻīl ibn Abī Zakarīyā ibn ʻAbd Allāh al-Muqrī eulogizing al-Malik al-Ashraf Ismāʻīl ibn al-ʻAbbās. The five following folios have a number of letters labelled by a later hand as independent of the MS, but evidently they are by al-Qīrāṭī as well. One of the letters is addressed to Taqī al-Dīn al-Maqrīzī, the famous historian 1365-1442.|Collation: Paper ; fol. (4) + 128 + (1) ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Layout: 23 lines per page.|Description: Rubricated ; a few lightly pink-tinted folios ; MS in fair condition.|Origin: According to colophon copied Sunday 19 Ṣafar 835 by Muḥammad ibn Aḥmad ibn ʻUthmān ... al-Mālikī (fol. 122a).|Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

author_as_recorded: Ibn Ḥijjah al-Ḥamawī, Taqī al-Dīn Abū Bakr ibn ʻAlī, -1434
author_as_recorded_agr: ابن حجة الحموي، تقي الدين ابو بكر بن علي، 1434
physical_description: Extent: 8 leaves : paper ; 176 x 117 (115 x 80) mm. bound to 182 x 126 mm.
note: Collation: Paper ; fol. iv + 8 + iv ; catchwords ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Description: Rubricated ; MS in poor condition ; folios 2, 4, 5 and 7 are foxed and mended with gauze.|Layout: 15 lines per page.|Marginal notes in different hands. The work was composed 797 (1394/95) in Maʻarrat al-Nuʻmān, where al-Ḥasan ibn ʻAlī ibn Muḥammad ibn Yaḥyá ibn Aḥmad ibn Muḥammad ibn Naṣr ibn Abī Bakr ʻAbd al-Razzāq ibn ʻAdb-al-Qādir al-Jīlānī, a descendant of the great Jīlānī, asked Ibn Ḥijjah to amplify the poem and showed him a previous amplification of the same poem by Ibn al-Ṣāḥib. Ibn Ḥijjah, not pleased with previous amplification, decided to have it appear side by side with his own in order to reveal the marked differences. Ironically he called the work Rashf al-Manhilayn, his own and that of Ibn al-Ṣāḥib. First paragraph of MS indicates that same man at whose request work was composed is also scribe to whom Ibn Ḥijjah dictated MS.|Ms. codex.|Title from title page (fol. 1a)|Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

author_as_recorded: Ibn al-Muqrī, Ismāʻīl ibn Abī Bakr, 1354-1433 or 1434
author_as_recorded_agr: ابن المقري، اسماعيل بن ابي بكر، 1354-1433 or 1434
scribe_as_recorded_agr: سمان، محمد بن عبد الرحمن
physical_description: Extent: 213 leaves : paper ; 220 x 144 (150 x 88) mm. bound to 220 x 160 mm.
note: Collation: Paper ; fol. 213 ; catchwords ; foliation in red in Hindu-Arabic numerals ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Decoration: Title page and first page illuminated. Title page frame-ruled with gold and blue. Title page includes a headpiece in gold, dark brown, light blue surrounding the author's name. The first page of the text has a gold headpiece with blue and white decoration and gold and blue frame-ruling. Folio 2a has gold and blue frame; subsequent folios have a blue single-line frame. Codex irregularly alternates between white, yellow, and red paper.|Description: Red, black and green headings throughout ; MS is rare ; MS in fair condition, many folios are worm-eaten with some mended.|Layout: 15 lines per page ; frame-ruled in blue ; verse separators in red or green.|Marginal notes. On folio 128 there is a ʻʻpoetical treeʼʼ in praise of al-Malik al-Nāṣir. MS of importance for the historical study of the Rasūlid period. The author occupied a teaching position in the Jihādīyah School at Taʻizz and in the Niẓāmīyah at Zabīd. He also acted as judge in the latter town.|Ms. codex.|Origin: According to colophon copied Tuesday 22 Shaʻbān 1000 by Muḥammad ibn ʻAbd al-Raḥmān al-Sammān (fol. 213b).|Title from title page (fol. 1a).|Ownership statements on title page, including one from ʻAbd al-Malik ibn ʻAbd Allāh ʻAbd al-Shakīr? written in a decorative frame above the title. Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

subject_label: Arabic poetry;Early works|Manuscripts, Arabic;New Jersey--Princeton|Arabic poetry|Manuscripts, Arabic|New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 209 leaves : paper ; 214 x 152 (165 x 100) mm. bound to 210 x 150 mm.
note: Collation: Paper ; fol. 209 ; catchwords; quires signed 2-14 ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Description: Rubricated ; verse separators in red ; MS in poor condition with text fully legible but extensive staining, warped pages, and partially detached and damaged binding.|Layout: 21 lines per page.|Marginal notes in different hands. Among the poets quoted in the first section are al-Tilimsānī (1213-1291), al-Bahāʼ Zuhayr (1258), Jamāl al-Dīn ibn Nubātah (1287-1366), Ṣafī al-Dīn al-Ḥillī (1278-1349), al-Arrajāni (1756), Ibn Zaydūn (1003-1070), Ibn al-Wardī (1290-1349), Ibn al-Muʻtazz (861-908) and others. Geometric designs and writing on pastedowns, including the name of the Prophet and the rāshidūn Caliphs.|Ms. codex.|Title from title page (fol. 1a).|Ownership signatures on the title page, some obliterated, include Muṣṭafá ibn Ḥasan al-Ṣaḥāwī al-Ḥanafī, Muṣṭafá ibn Ḥusayn ibn Kamāl al-Dīn al-Ḥusaynī dated 1087, and Zayn al-Dīn al-Shaṭ... al-Madanī. Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.
